video.title: How to Put a Website Online: Template, Coding, Domain, Hosting, and DNS
video.description:
Learn how to get your website online with a custom URL and website hosting.

The template website referenced in this video is down. Get the template here: https://drive.google.com/file/d/1Zr80JIe30eJEUIx_8o1inyHHru18T4mQ/view?usp=sharing

In this course, you will first learn how to create a simple website using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript, starting with a website template. (If you already have a website—great! Just skip this section and go to the next one.) Then, you will learn how to get a custom URL. Finally, you will learn how to host your website files and make your custom URL point to your website files. You will learn two different ways to host your website, including a way to host your website for free!

This course was created by Beau Carnes.

🔗 Get a .TECH domain name: https://get.tech

🔗 Learn more about HTML and CSS: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLWKjhJtqVAbnSe1qUNMG7AbPmjIG54u88

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (00:00) Introduction
⌨️ (00:34) Creating a website
⌨️ (38:41) Getting a custom URL
⌨️ (42:45) Getting web hosting
⌨️ (48:25) Creating a custom email address
⌨️ (48:25) Updating Nameservers
⌨️ (51:35) Hosting for free with GitHub Pages
⌨️ (56:08) Updating DNS Settings
⌨️ (59:15) Conclusion

⭐️ Special thanks to our Champion supporters! ⭐️ 
🏆 Loc Do
🏆 Joseph C
🏆 DeezMaster

This course was made possible in part by a grant from Radix, who own the .tech TLD.

topLevelComment.author: Peter Sedesse
topLevelComment.text:
when attaching your domain name to your actual hosting,  as he said, it can take more than 12 hours before you can use the domain name to see your website. However, on your hosting site, they will give you an IP address, which is just http: followed by a lot of numbers.  You can type the IP address into your browser to see your website while waiting for the domain name to work. 

When I first started doing websites (back in the stone ages), I was always a little paranoid if I had uploaded my files to the correct folder on the hosting site.  Using the IP address during those initial 12-48 hours allows you to verify you uploaded correctly even before the domain name is ready.

replies.author: Sourav Das
replies.text:
No, Django websites are not static. They are dynamic. You have to use Django on a Dedicated server (DigitalOcean, Linode etc), or on any PaaS (such as Heroku, PythonAnywhere etc). You have to add few more configurations such as Gunicorn (can be used with Heroku) etc. 
You can watch any video related to this. But I will recommend you the videos by Corey Schafer. He has a Django playlist, at the end of which, he shows several ways to host a Django website. Hope this helps :)

replies.author: Sourav Das
replies.text:
Yes, you can use Django or Flask to create websites using Python code. I will recommend you to watch Django or Flask series by Corey Schafer. His videos are amazing for a beginner. 

Flask is light, easier than Django, whereas Django is robust, and slightly harder than Flask. If you want to wash a plate, then the tap is Flask. You have to arrange soap and cloth using your technique to wash the dish/plate. Whereas the whole kitchen will be Django. You can also customise your kitchen as you want, but a little bit harder because Django is monolithic. You have to dive deep into Django official source code if you, for example, want to customise user login/signup in your website.

replies.author: Sourav Das
replies.text:
You can use advanced frameworks, using which, data can be stored in your website in database. So, you don't have to add code everytime whenever you write a new post. It is basic CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete). Learning a framework can be very hard at first. But as you do things repeatedly and regularly, it will become easy. 
Example of some frameworks (Django, ExpressJS). If you want a different frontend framework, then VueJS, ReactJS alongwith Django or ExpressJS etc.

replies.author: tru th
replies.text: Servers are essentially just computers. So they work by interacting with operating systems. Node is a js runtime environment that lets you write in javascript but it uses another language (i believe c#, but I may be wrong, to interact with the OS itself). Not sure if that's basic to you or not, but it confused me for quite sometime when I just started. If it did help you though, and you're interested in server side languages as opposed to javascript on server then perhaps a class on C or Java may help you. I've honestly been a fairly strict JS developer so that's out of any knowledge I have but just in case you're a newb like I was I figured I'd share that
